title: Field to Fork 2019: Best Management Practices to Produce More Potatoes

tasks.task: Conducting a gardening presentation about potato cultivation including breeding and management practices.
subtasks: Describe potato taxonomy and botany (e.g., Solanaceae family, stem modification, herbaceous dicot nature).
Highlight potato production significance (e.g., industry value, Minnesota vs North Dakota rankings, seed potato certification).
Explain market classes of potatoes (round whites, long russets, reds, heirlooms) based on texture and culinary use.
Discuss potato nutritional benefits (low calorie, high fiber, potassium content) and debunk common myths.
Outline the potato breeding history at NDSU (1930 start, cultivar releases, recent advancements).
Cover potato growing conditions (cool season, temperature preferences, water requirement, pH considerations).
Differentiate propagation methods (clonal vs seed potato), focusing on asexual reproduction in home gardens.
Address planting and spacing techniques for backyard gardens (row width, plant spacing, hill formation, fertilization).
Introduce pest and disease management strategies (weed control, insect identification, common scab mitigation, storage practices).
Answer live questions via Q&A session on topics such as viral seed potatoes, potato scab management, and suitable cultivars for storage boxes.
Summarize key best practices for increasing potato productivity in small-scale production.
